original: Getting to space is hard. Right now it's like going up a mountain on a U-cycle with a backpack full of explosives. Incredibly slow, you can't transport a lot of stuff and you might die. A rocket needs to reach a velocity of about 40,000 kilometres now to escape from Earth. To get to that speed, rockets are mostly containers for fuel with a tiny tip of payload. This is bad if you want to go to other planet because you need a lot of heavy stuff if you want to survive and maybe even come back. So is there a way to get a space with less fuel and more payload? A nice thing that solved most of our transport problems on Earth is what you call infrastructure. Whether it's roads for cars, ports for ships or rails for trains, we've made it easier to get to places. We can apply the same solution to space travel. Space infrastructure will make getting into orbit and out to the moon, Mars and beyond, easier and cheaper. Great, but what exactly is space infrastructure? Unlike an Earth Space elevator which is currently science fiction, there is a simple yet promising technology that does not require new science. Magic materials or huge investments and that has been tested successfully in orbit already. A cable and a weight, known as a tavern. The concept is so simple, it's surprising. What if we put taverns, hundreds or thousands of kilometres long into space and had space craft to use them as ladders to climb to higher altitude's and gain speed? This concept is known as the Skyhook. It works even better if we make it spin. The counterweight holds a long cable in place while it rotates around a circle. A rotating teather slows down its tip relative to the ground at the bottom and speeds it up at the top like a catapult. This means that you can transfer energy from the teather and get a massive boost when released, more or less for free, equal to twice the teather's rotation velocity. The specialised fibers already exist that can survive the extraordinary stresses a skyhook would be faced with. To protect against cuts and collisions from debris and meteorites, we can thread our teather into a web of redundant fibers. Since our skyhook would pass over the same spot many times a day, this would allow small, reusable shuttles to catch up with it. Of course, it's not that easy. At its lowest point, the teather's tip is dashing through the atmosphere at around 12,000 kilometres per hour. Because of Earth's atmosphere, we can't know the skyhook too much or it will get too hot from air friction. So it will dip to a height of 80 to 150 kilometres and no lower. To match this, we'll need specialised space craft that can get to the teather. While this isn't exactly easy, it's still much cheaper than getting a big tin can, filled with a rocket fuel to go 40,000 kilometres an hour. Catching the tip will be a challenge too. There's only a short time window of 62-90 seconds to find a tiny thing in the sky, moving at Mark 12. To make this easier, the tip could have a sort of fishing line, a colloiter long with an navigation drone that helps the spacecraft connect. Another challenge is keeping our skyhook in orbit. As more and more ships latch onto it and pull themselves up, they use up the momentum that keeps it in place. If we don't do anything, it will slow down and crash into the atmosphere. And here, we can cheat the universe a bit. The skyhook is a battery of orbital energy. It's possible to balance the payloads coming in and being set off. Arriving ships, bringing humans and materials home to Earth, add energy to the teather, which it can give to other ships departing into space. This way the teather doesn't lose any energy. The more we use it, the cheaper it gets. If we're still losing energy with each boost, we can recover it with smaller electric or chemical engines that regularly correct the teather's position. The set of tevers, one around Earth and one around Mars, could make trips between the planets fast, straight forward and low-cost compared to rockets. The Earth teather would sit in low Earth orbit to grab people and payloads and fling them off to Mars. The Mars teather catches them and slows them down for landing on the surface. In the opposite direction, the teather could pick up a vehicle travelling through Mars' thin atmosphere at only about 1,000 kilometres an hour, not much faster than our airliner's on Earth and fling it back to Earth to be caught and lower down. The tevers could shorten trips between both planets from my months down to 5 or even 3 and reduce the scale of the rockets required by between 84 and 96%. Even better, people may be able to travel in a relative luxury as we could afford to invest in passenger comfort. Teather travel would be first class seats to Mars. Together, tevers around Earth and Mars could provide the rapid and cost-efficient transportation backbone that would make space travel affordable. But let's go further. Starting from low Mars orbit, a teather could boost ships to the asteroid belt. The first craft sent to a new asteroid would need rockets to slow down at its destination. Subsequent arrivals might find a teather waiting to catch them and send them back for free. Listening to asteroids cheaply is a major factor in opening up the resources of the solar system. Pressure metals and valuable minerals could be delivered to Mars just weeks after they were cut out of their asteroid. They would be the perfect building blocks for our interplanetary civilization. But why stop here? Mars moons are very convenient. No other moons in the solar system orbit that close to their planet. The focus is so heavy that we don't need to worry about slowing it down, making it the perfect attachment point for supertellers just under 6,000 kilometers long. The lower tip would fly just over the surface of Mars and be very easy to catch. The upper tip can fling ships all the way to Jupiter and Saturn. The same supertether can also bring the inner solar system closer. Venus and Mercury are a single swing away. Unlike Mars, they're bursting with solar energy and our rich in minerals. In the long term, nothing is stopping humanity from constructing a zero-prepetent transport network for the terrestrial planets centered on the Martian moons.
